column12: Emissions of air pollutants from all sectors
column13: Measured in tonnes and split by major pollutant.

column12: Per capita emissions of air pollutants from all sectors

column12: Ammonia emissions by sector
column13: Ammonia (NH₃) is a gas which can mix with other gases – such as nitrogen oxides and sulphur dioxide – to form particulate matter. Its main sources are the use of manure and fertilizers in agriculture, and emissions from industry.

column12: Per capita ammonia emissions by sector
column13: Ammonia (NH₃) is a gas which can mix with other gases – such as nitrogen oxides and sulphur dioxide – to form particulate matter. Its main sources are the use of manure and fertilizers in agriculture, and emissions from industry.

column12: Black carbon emissions by sector
column13: Black carbon (BC) is a soot-like pollutant formed from the burning of biomass and fossil fuels. It is a major contributor to particulate matter pollution, and contributes to climate change by absorbing sunlight.

column12: Per capita black carbon emissions by sector
column13: Black carbon (BC) is a soot-like pollutant formed from the burning of biomass and fossil fuels. It is a major contributor to particulate matter pollution, and contributes to climate change by absorbing sunlight.

column12: Carbon monoxide emissions by sector
column13: Carbon monoxide (CO) is a pollutant produced from the incomplete combustion of carbon-based fuels such as oil, gas, wood, and coal. CO is a harmful gas that contributes to both outdoor and indoor air pollution.

column12: Per capita carbon monoxide emissions by sector
column13: Carbon monoxide (CO) is a pollutant produced from the incomplete combustion of carbon-based fuels such as oil, gas, wood, and coal. CO is a harmful gas that contributes to both outdoor and indoor air pollution.

column12: Methane emissions by sector
column13: Methane (CH₄) is a greenhouse gas that contributes to the formation of ground-level ozone, a harmful air pollutant. Key sources of methane include agriculture, landfills, and fossil fuel extraction.

column12: Per capita methane emissions by sector
column13: Methane (CH₄) is a greenhouse gas that contributes to the formation of ground-level ozone, a harmful air pollutant. Key sources of methane include agriculture, landfills, and fossil fuel extraction.

column12: Nitrogen oxides emissions by sector
column13: Nitrogen oxides (NOₓ) are gases that are mainly formed during the burning of fossil fuels. Exposure to NOₓ gases can have negative impacts on respiratory health. NOₓ gases can also lead to the formation of ozone – another air pollutant.

column12: Per capita nitrogen oxides emissions by sector
column13: Nitrogen oxides (NOₓ) are gases that are mainly formed during the burning of fossil fuels. Exposure to NOₓ gases can have negative impacts on respiratory health. NOₓ gases can also lead to the formation of ozone – another air pollutant.

column12: Nitrous oxide emissions by sector
column13: Nitrous oxide (N₂O) is a greenhouse gas that contributes to air pollution by depleting the stratospheric ozone layer and influencing atmospheric chemistry. Major sources include agriculture, industrial processes, and fossil fuel combustion.

column12: Per capita nitrous oxide emissions by sector
column13: Nitrous oxide (N₂O) is a greenhouse gas that contributes to air pollution by depleting the stratospheric ozone layer and influencing atmospheric chemistry. Major sources include agriculture, industrial processes, and fossil fuel combustion.

column12: Non-methane volatile organic compounds emissions by sector
column13: Non-methane volatile organic compounds (NMVOCs) are pollutants formed from the burning of biomass and fossil fuels. NMVOCs can lead to the formation of other local air pollutants, such as ozone.

column12: Per capita non-methane volatile organic compounds emissions by sector
column13: Non-methane volatile organic compounds (NMVOCs) are pollutants formed from the burning of biomass and fossil fuels. NMVOCs can lead to the formation of other local air pollutants, such as ozone.

column12: Organic carbon emissions by sector
column13: Organic carbon molecules are formed from the incomplete burning of organic materials, including fossil fuels and biomass. They can also be suspended in the air from sources such as vehicle tyres and roads. Organic carbon adds to particulate matter pollution, with negative impacts on human health.

column12: Per capita organic carbon emissions by sector
column13: Organic carbon molecules are formed from the incomplete burning of organic materials, including fossil fuels and biomass. They can also be suspended in the air from sources such as vehicle tyres and roads. Organic carbon adds to particulate matter pollution, with negative impacts on human health.

column12: Sulfur dioxide emissions by sector
column13: Sulphur dioxide (SO₂) is an air pollutant formed from the burning of fuels that contain sulphur, such as coal. SO₂ is one of the main chemicals that forms acid rain.

column12: Per capita sulfur dioxide emissions by sector
column13: Sulphur dioxide (SO₂) is an air pollutant formed from the burning of fuels that contain sulphur, such as coal. SO₂ is one of the main chemicals that forms acid rain.
